title: 114_hr4661
content: The "Parent PLUS Loan Improvement Act of 2016" establishes the applicable rate of interest for PLUS loans. The Parent PLUS Loan Improvement Act of 2016 amends the applicable rate of interest for Federal Direct PLUS Loans made on behalf of dependent students, reducing the interest rate to 3.6 percent and 9.5 percent for first disbursements made on or after July 1, 2016. The Parent PLUS Loan Improvement Act of 2016 eliminates the origination fee for Parent PLUS loans and requires counseling for Parent PLUS borrowers. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require comprehensive counseling for Parent PLUS borrowers before disbursement of a Federal Direct PLUS loan. The counseling must use interactive programs to ensure understanding of loan terms and conditions in simple language. The counseling session for Parent PLUS borrowers must be conducted in person or online. Information provided includes details on interest accrual, loan repayment start, deferment options, and available repayment plans with personalized payment estimates. The counseling session for Parent PLUS borrowers includes details on repayment plans, interest accrual, consequences of default, and contact information for questions. The counseling session for Parent PLUS borrowers covers repayment plans, interest accrual, consequences of default, and contact information for questions about borrower's rights and responsibilities or loan terms and conditions. SEC. 5. INCLUSION OF PARENT PLUS LOANS IN INCOME-CONTINGENT AND INCOME-BASED REPAYMENT PLANS. The text chunk discusses amending the Income-Contingent Repayment Plan and the Income-Based Repayment plan under the Higher Education Act of 1965. It includes changes related to Federal Direct PLUS loans and partial financial hardship definitions. Amendments are made to the Income-Contingent Repayment Plan and the Income-Based Repayment plan under the Higher Education Act of 1965, specifically regarding Federal Direct PLUS loans and partial financial hardship definitions. The changes involve removing certain loan exceptions in various subsections. The plan described in this subparagraph is not available for borrowers of Federal Direct PLUS Loans or Federal Direct Consolidation Loans if the loan proceeds were used to pay off a previous loan. The Secretary will ensure that all Federal Direct PLUS Loans and loans under section 428B of the Higher Education Act of 1965 made for dependent students are eligible for any repayment plan authorized under the Act or its regulations.
